text:
Drupal Developer Days (Drupal Dev Days - DDD) is an event organized by the Drupal community which gather people from across Europe who develops and works with Drupal. Started in 2010 in Munich, the DDD, travels every year through different cities.

The Drupal Dev Days are a good opportunity for work shoulder to shoulder with other developers who cultivates the same interests... Moreover it’s a great time to start new collaborations!

  • Drupal Dev Days Montpellier | 13 - 19 April 2015 Montpellier, France http://montpellier2015.drupaldays.org
  • Drupal Dev Days Szeged | 24 - 30 March 2014 Szeged, Hungary http://szeged2014.drupaldays.org
  • Drupal Dev Days Dublin | 28 - 30 June 2013 Dublin, Ireland http://dublin2013.drupaldays.org
  • Drupal Dev Days Barcelona | 14 - 16 June 2012 Barcelona, Spain http://barcelona2012.drupaldays.org
  • Drupal Dev Days Brussels | 4 - 6 February 2011 Brussels, Belgium · http://bxl2011.drupaldays.org
  • Drupal Dev Days | 8 - 9 May 2010 Munich, Germany (site no longer online)

At the core of Drupal Dev Days stands a three-day-long set of presentations focused on Drupal, PHP and web development.Here you can find the sessions program, with links to detailed descriptions.

If you want to host a session yourself, please have a look at our “Call for Papers” and “Speaker guidelines” pages.

The sessions schedule will be available soon.

As with other Drupal community events, the focus of Drupal Dev Days is on sharing experiences with other attendees, eager to learn about the latest tricks, best practices, tools, and whatever can take the Drupal Developer skills and productivity to the next level.You are invited to submit here your session proposal by filling out the form below.

Another sharing opportunity that community events offer to Drupal people is the chance to code along with peers and colleagues for long, fun days.

At the moment, we can predict the main focus of sprints will be on these subjects:

  • Sprint subject 1
  • Sprint subject 2
  • Sprint subject 3

Remember: sprints are not only for Drupal coders! Also people with little knowledge of Drupal’s internals can contribute with tests and documentation.

Also, sprints will be mentored by experienced developers who will offer helpful insights to beginners.

Of course you will be able to hang out randomly with other attendees in the venue’s common spaces, but we’re planning also some organized activities that will make your stay in Milano even more fun and interesting.

More details to be announced on this page in the weeks before the event.

For the “unconference-style” die-hard fans, spaces will be available to organize informal meetings and sessions where people can discuss a common Drupal-related matter of interest.

In the weeks before the event, and at the event itself, some loose guidelines will be published in order to be able to schedule time-slots for such discussions.

If you want to sponsor the 2016 Drupal Dev Days, please contact us, using this website’s contact information and contact form.

Here’s a handy collection of dates that you might want to add to your agenda, so you won’t miss a beat.

The most important dates are of course the ones of the real thing: 21-26 June 2016.Check early travel options, in order to find bargains and reduced fares.

But first…

  • If you want to save some money, take advantage of the Early Bird Pricing, which is available only until: xxxxxxxx
  • If you want to be on THAT podium, make sure you submit your session proposal before the C4P deadline on: xxxxxxxx

The Scholarship program aims at supporting Drupal community members who wouldn’t be able to attend the event without financial help. A part of the budget for Drupal Dev Days 2016 contributes partially to travel and accommodation expenses for a limited number of attendees, who are selected by the DDD organizing committee after receiving applications through a form on this website.

Click here to apply for the Scholarship program. Deadline is Sunday 3 April 2016 (00.00am CET).

The Scholarship program is funded through the Drupal Association.

Our good old friend Druplicon is now presented in a “leonardesque” manner. Several graphic components of the website reproduce or are inspired by his works, from the ornithopter to the machinery his inventions were made of. Although not a native, Leonardo spent in Milano a significant part of his life, leaving an invaluable cultural legacy culminating in the marvellous Last Supper, which you don’t really want to miss when you will come to Milano. Thus, make sure you book in advance the visit to Santa Maria delle Grazie!
